title: William J. Coyne
text:
William Joseph Coyne (August 24, 1936 – November 3, 2013) was a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic</a> member of the <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">United States House of Representatives</a> from <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> from 1981 to 2003.
Early life and education.
Coyne was born in <a href="Pittsburgh%2C%20Pennsylvania">Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania</a>. He graduated from <a href="Central%20Catholic%20High%20School%20%28Pittsburgh%2C%20Pennsylvania%29">Central Catholic High School</a> in 1954, and received a <a href="B.S.">B.S.</a> in accounting from <a href="Robert%20Morris%20University">Robert Morris College</a>.
He served for two years in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> in 1955–1957. He served as a supply sergeant in Korea. After completing his military service, he set up a private accounting firm.
Political career.
From 1970 to 1972 he was member of the <a href="Pennsylvania%20House%20of%20Representatives">Pennsylvania House of Representatives</a>, and a member of the <a href="Pittsburgh%20City%20Council">Pittsburgh City Council</a> from 1974 to 1980.
Congress.
Coyne was elected to Congress in 1980, succeeding 24-year incumbent <a href="William%20S.%20Moorhead">William S. Moorhead</a> in a district taking in most of Pittsburgh. He was reelected ten times, never facing serious opposition. He was a longtime member of the <a href="United%20States%20House%20Committee%20on%20Ways%20and%20Means">United States House Committee on Ways and Means</a>
Retirement and death.
In 2002, Coyne's district was combined with the district of <a href="Michael%20F.%20Doyle">Mike Doyle</a>, a somewhat more moderate Democrat. Although the new district contained more of Coyne's territory than Doyle's, Coyne retired to avoid the possibility of two Democratic <a href="incumbents">incumbents</a> facing each other in the <a href="primary%20elections">primary elections</a>.
Coyne died at the age of 77 on November 3, 2013, two months after falling and sustaining head injuries.
